entries.content: Let me also read the pre-registration spec to understand the battle pass details:

entries.detail:
1→# Pre-Registration Specification - Complete System Overview
     2→
     3→> *"47 fans. That's all I have. But every single one of you keeps me existing. Now, let me show you what your Devotion can become..."*
     4→> — Ika Minami, Pre-Registration Launch Day
     5→
     6→---
     7→
     8→## Overview
     9→
    10→The **Infinite Idol Pre-Registration System** is the complete economic and progression framework that powers player engagement on the SUI blockchain. Built with dark luxury aesthetics and whale psychology principles, this system transforms fan Devotion into tangible rewards while maintaining the existential stakes central to the Infinite Idol narrative.
    11→
    12→This document provides a comprehensive overview of all core mechanics. For detailed specifications on individual systems, see the cross-referenced files at the end of this document.
    13→
    14→---
    15→
    16→## Core Systems Summary
    17→
    18→The pre-registration experience consists of 16 interconnected systems:
    19→
    20→| # | System | Purpose | Primary Currency |
    21→|---|--------|---------|------------------|
    22→| 1 | GEM SYSTEM | Currency acquisition and conversion | SUI → Gems |
    23→| 2 | Daily Check-In | Engagement rewards | Time → Gems |
    24→| 3 | Leveling | Progression milestones | Gems → Levels |
    25→| 4 | Battle Pass | Account representation (NFT) | N/A (Tracking) |
    26→| 5 | Lootbox | Reward containers | N/A (Earned) |
    27→| 6 | Items | Cosmetic equipment | Lootboxes → Items |
    28→| 7 | Pets | Companion collectibles | Pet Eggs → Pets |
    29→| 8 | Burn | Duplicate recycling | Items → Lootboxes |
    30→| 9 | Inventory | Asset management | N/A (Storage) |
    31→| 10 | Checkbook | Collection tracking | N/A (Display) |
    32→| 11 | Wallet Connection | Blockchain integration | N/A (Auth) |
    33→| 12 | Battle Pass Trading | Account transfer | SUI |
    34→| 13 | Cosmetic Trading | Item marketplace | SUI |
    35→| 14 | Notifications | User feedback | N/A (UX) |
    36→| 15 | User Profile | Stats tracking | N/A (Display) |
    37→| 16 | Randomness | Fair loot distribution | N/A (Backend) |
    38→
    39→---
    40→
    41→## 1. GEM SYSTEM
    42→
    43→### The Foundation of All Economy
    44→
    45→Gems are the primary in-game currency. Everything in the pre-registration flows through Gems.
    46→
    47→**Core Conversion Rate:** 1 SUI = 100 Gems
    48→
    49→### Gem Package Tiers
    50→
    51→| SUI Spent | Gems Received | Bonus | Total Value |
    52→|-----------|---------------|-------|-------------|
    53→| 1 SUI | 100 Gems | 0% | Base rate |
    54→| 10 SUI | 1,100 Gems | 10% | +100 bonus |
    55→| 100 SUI | 11,500 Gems | 15% | +1,500 bonus |
    56→| 1,000 SUI | 120,000 Gems | 20% | +20,000 bonus |
    57→| 10,000 SUI | 1,250,000 Gems | 25% | +250,000 bonus |
    58→| 100,000 SUI | 13,000,000 Gems | 30% | +3,000,000 bonus |
    59→
    60→### Key Rules
    61→
    62→- **Account-Bound**: Gems are stored per wallet address and cannot be transferred
    63→- **Spending**: 69 Gems = 1 Level (Idol Aura)
    64→- **Admin Control**: Conversion rates can be adjusted by admin
    65→- **Visual Feedback**: Each package tier has unique purchase animations
    66→
    67→> *For complete gem system details, see `knowledge-base/game-mechanics/gem-system.md`*
    68→
    69→---
    70→
    71→## 2. Daily Check-In System
    72→
    73→### Engagement Through Consistency
    74→
    75→Free gems for showing up. Streak milestones reward dedication.
    76→
    77→**Base Reward:** 10 Gems per day
    78→
    79→### Streak Milestones
    80→
    81→| Consecutive Days | Bonus Reward |
    82→|------------------|--------------|
    83→| 7 days | +50 Gems |
    84→| 14 days | +100 Gems + 1 Lootbox + 1 Pet Egg |
    85→| 21 days | +200 Gems |
    86→| 30 days | +500 Gems + 1 Golden Lootbox + Special Badge |
    87→
    88→### Rules
    89→
    90→- 24-hour cooldown starts when you claim (not at midnight)
    91→- Missing a claim resets streak to 0
    92→- Streak data stored in Battle Pass NFT
    93→- Streak resets if Battle Pass is traded to new owner
    94→
    95→---
    96→
    97→## 3. Leveling System
    98→
    99→### Permanent Progression
   100→
   101→**Cost:** 69 Gems = 1 Idol Aura (Level)
   102→
   103→### Milestone Rewards (Automatic)
   104→
   105→| Milestone | Reward |
   106→|-----------|--------|
   107→| Every 1 level | 1 Lootbox (A→B→C→D→E rotating) |
   108→| Every 50 levels | 1 Pet Egg |
   109→| Every 1,000 levels | 1 Golden Lootbox |
   110→| Every 10,000 levels | 1 Diamond Lootbox |
   111→
   112→### Rules
   113→
   114→- Levels are permanent (never decrease)
   115→- Maximum level: 999,999
   116→- Level stored in Battle Pass NFT
   117→- Cannot skip levels
   118→
   119→---
   120→
   121→## 4. Battle Pass System
   122→
   123→### Your Identity on the Eternal Stage
   124→
   125→The Battle Pass is an NFT that represents your complete account progress.
   126→
   127→**Creation:** Automatically minted when you first spend gems
   128→
   129→### Tracked Data
   130→
   131→- Current level
   132→- Total SUI spent
   133→- Daily check-in streak
   134→- Total gems earned from dailies
   135→- Mint date
   136→- Season number
   137→
   138→### Visual Tiers
   139→
   140→The Battle Pass appearance evolves with your level:
   141→
   142→| Level Range | Tier | Aesthetic |
   143→|-------------|------|-----------|
   144→| 1-99 | Bronze | Base tier |
   145→| 100-999 | Silver | Refined |
   146→| 1,000-9,999 | Gold | Premium |
   147→| 10,000-99,999 | Platinum | Elite |
   148→| 100,000-420,068 | Diamond | Legendary |
   149→| 420,069+ | Cosmic | Ultimate |
   150→
   151→### Trading Rules
   152→
   153→- Cannot trade current-season Battle Pass
   154→- Trading resets streak to 0
   155→- One Battle Pass per wallet maximum
   156→
   157→> *For complete Battle Pass details, see `knowledge-base/game-mechanics/battle-pass.md`*
   158→
   159→---
   160→
   161→## 5. Lootbox System
   162→
   163→### The Thrill of the Chase (For Items)
   164→
   165→NFT containers earned at level milestones. Opening burns the lootbox and creates items.
   166→
   167→### Lootbox Types
   168→
   169→| Type | Source | Contents |
   170→|------|--------|----------|
   171→| A Box | Level milestones (position 1 in cycle) | A-family cosmetic sets |
   172→| B Box | Level milestones (position 2 in cycle) | B-family cosmetic sets |
   173→| C Box | Level milestones (position 3 in cycle) | C-family cosmetic sets |
   174→| D Box | Level milestones (position 4 in cycle) | D-family cosmetic sets |
   175→| E Box | Level milestones (position 5 in cycle) | E-family cosmetic sets |
   176→| Golden Lootbox | 1,000-level milestones, 30-day streak | Better odds |
   177→| Diamond Lootbox | 10,000-level milestones | Best odds |
   178→
   179→### Cycling Pattern
   180→
   181→Lootboxes cycle A→B→C→D→E→A... as you level:
   182→- Level 1 → A Box
   183→- Level 2 → B Box
   184→- Level 3 → C Box
   185→- Level 4 → D Box
   186→- Level 5 → E Box
   187→- Level 6 → A Box (repeat)
   188→
   189→### Time-Locked Releases
   190→
   191→| Box Type | Availability |
   192→|----------|--------------|
   193→| A Box | Day 1 |
   194→| B Box | 3 weeks after launch |
   195→| C Box | 6 weeks after launch |
   196→| D Box | 9 weeks after launch |
   197→| E Box | 12 weeks after launch |
   198→
   199→### Rarity Odds (Standard Boxes)
   200→
   201→| Rarity | Chance |
   202→|--------|--------|
   203→| Common | 60% |
   204→| Rare | 25% |
   205→| Ultra Rare | 12% |
   206→| Legendary | 3% |
   207→
   208→> *For complete lootbox details, see `knowledge-base/game-mechanics/gacha-system.md`*
   209→
   210→---
   211→
   212→## 6. Item System
   213→
   214→### Dressing IKA-Chan for the Chase
   215→
   216→Cosmetic pieces from lootboxes. NFTs that can be equipped, collected, or burned.
   217→
   218→### Item Slots (9 Total)
   219→
   220→| Slot | Type | Source |
   221→|------|------|--------|
   222→| Head | Core piece | Family boxes |
   223→| Chest | Core piece | Family boxes |
   224→| Arms | Core piece | Family boxes |
   225→| Legs | Core piece | Family boxes |
   226→| Feet | Core piece | Family boxes |
   227→| Back | Core piece | Family boxes |
   228→| Neck | Accessory | Any box |
   229→| L Wrist | Accessory | Any box |
   230→| R Wrist | Accessory | Any box |
   231→
   232→### Collection Scale
   233→
   234→- **30 complete outfit sets** (270 total pieces possible)
   235→- Each set has up to 6 pieces (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back)
   236→- Accessories drop from any box type
   237→
   238→### Rarity Tiers
   239→
   240→| Tier | Description |
   241→|------|-------------|
   242→| Common | Basic designs |
   243→| Rare | Enhanced details |
   244→| Ultra Rare | Special effects/patterns |
   245→| Legendary | Premium exclusive designs |
   246→
   247→> *For complete cosmetics details, see `knowledge-base/game-mechanics/cosmetics.md`*
   248→
   249→---
   250→
   251→## 7. Pet System
   252→
   253→### Companions on the Eternal Stage
   254→
   255→Collectible creatures that appear alongside IKA-Chan.
   256→
   257→**Acquisition:** Pet Eggs earned at level 50 milestones and 14-day streak
   258→
   259→**Opening Cost:** 420 Gems (approximately $5 USD equivalent)
   260→
   261→### Pet Variants
   262→
   263→| Rarity | Variants | Chance |
   264→|--------|----------|--------|
   265→| Common | 12 colors | 70% |
   266→| Rare | 4 textures | 20% |
   267→| Ultra Rare | 2 with effects | 8% |
   268→| Cosmic Rare | 1 animated | 2% |
   269→
   270→### Mechanics
   271→
   272→- Eggs can be traded unopened
   273→- Hatched pets can be traded
   274→- Burn 5 duplicate pets → 1 Pet Egg
   275→- Pets are purely cosmetic (no stats)
   276→
   277→---
   278→
   279→## 8. Burn System
   280→
   281→### Devotion Recycling
   282→
   283→Destroy duplicates to get new chances at rare items.
   284→
   285→### Burn Types
   286→
   287→| Method | Input | Output |
   288→|--------|-------|--------|
   289→| Regular Burn | 4 duplicate items | 1 Lootbox (same type) |
   290→| Prestige Burn (4,000) | Lifetime 4,000 items

entries.detail:
1→# GACHA SYSTEM - Complete Lootbox Mechanics
     2→
     3→> *"Every box you open is another roll in The Chase. The odds are published. The thrill is real. And somewhere in that 3%... your Legendary awaits."*
     4→> — Ika Minami, Lootbox Tutorial
     5→
     6→---
     7→
     8→## Overview
     9→
    10→The **Gacha System** is the core reward mechanism of Infinite Idol's pre-registration experience. Lootboxes are NFT containers earned through progression milestones—never purchased directly. Opening a lootbox burns the NFT and creates new cosmetic item NFTs based on published probability tables.
    11→
    12→This system is designed around transparent odds, time-gated content releases, and the thrill of the chase—echoing the narrative's core premise where idols pursue Senpai across the Eternal Stage.
    13→
    14→---
    15→
    16→## Rarity Tiers
    17→
    18→All lootbox contents follow a unified rarity system:
    19→
    20→| Rarity | Drop Chance | Visual Treatment | Description |
    21→|--------|-------------|------------------|-------------|
    22→| **Common** | 60% | Silver border, subtle shimmer | Basic designs, foundational pieces |
    23→| **Rare** | 25% | Gold border, gentle glow | Enhanced details, refined aesthetics |
    24→| **Ultra Rare** | 12% | Purple border, particle effects | Special effects, unique patterns |
    25→| **Legendary** | 3% | Black + gold flames, full animation | Premium exclusive designs, ultimate prestige |
    26→
    27→### Rarity Philosophy
    28→
    29→The 60/25/12/3 distribution is intentional:
    30→
    31→| Rarity | Purpose | Player Psychology |
    32→|--------|---------|-------------------|
    33→| Common (60%) | Collection building | Satisfying progress, completionism fuel |
    34→| Rare (25%) | Excitement spikes | "Better than common!" dopamine |
    35→| Ultra Rare (12%) | Goal creation | Pursuit targets, collection prestige |
    36→| Legendary (3%) | Dream pulls | Ultimate chase goal, flex material |
    37→
    38→---
    39→
    40→## Lootbox Types
    41→
    42→### Standard Family Boxes (A-E)
    43→
    44→Five distinct lootbox families, each containing cosmetics from their respective set:
    45→
    46→| Box Type | Cosmetic Family | Content Focus |
    47→|----------|-----------------|---------------|
    48→| **A Box** | A-family sets | 6 outfit sets (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back) |
    49→| **B Box** | B-family sets | 6 outfit sets (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back) |
    50→| **C Box** | C-family sets | 6 outfit sets (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back) |
    51→| **D Box** | D-family sets | 6 outfit sets (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back) |
    52→| **E Box** | E-family sets | 6 outfit sets (Head, Chest, Arms, Legs, Feet, Back) |
    53→
    54→Each family contains 6 complete outfit sets × 6 pieces = 36 items per family.
    55→
    56→### Premium Boxes
    57→
    58→Higher-tier lootboxes with improved odds:
    59→
    60→| Box Type | Source | Improved Odds | Special Features |
    61→|----------|--------|---------------|------------------|
    62→| **Golden Lootbox** | 1,000-level milestones, 30-day streaks | 2× Legendary chance (6%) | Any family cosmetics |
    63→| **Diamond Lootbox** | 10,000-level milestones, Prestige Burn (40,000) | 3× Legendary chance (9%) | Any family + exclusive items |
    64→
    65→### Golden Lootbox Odds
    66→
    67→| Rarity | Standard Chance | Golden Chance |
    68→|--------|-----------------|---------------|
    69→| Common | 60% | 45% |
    70→| Rare | 25% | 30% |
    71→| Ultra Rare | 12% | 19% |
    72→| Legendary | 3% | 6% |
    73→
    74→### Diamond Lootbox Odds
    75→
    76→| Rarity | Standard Chance | Diamond Chance |
    77→|--------|-----------------|----------------|
    78→| Common | 60% | 30% |
    79→| Rare | 25% | 35% |
    80→| Ultra Rare | 12% | 26% |
    81→| Legendary | 3% | 9% |
    82→
    83→---
    84→
    85→## Time-Locked Releases
    86→
    87→Content is staggered to maintain long-term engagement and create anticipation:
    88→
    89→| Box Type | Availability | Days After Launch |
    90→|----------|--------------|-------------------|
    91→| **A Box** | Day 1 | 0 |
    92→| **B Box** | 3 weeks after launch | 21 |
    93→| **C Box** | 6 weeks after launch | 42 |
    94→| **D Box** | 9 weeks after launch | 63 |
    95→| **E Box** | 12 weeks after launch | 84 |
    96→
    97→### Time-Lock Philosophy
    98→
    99→| Purpose | Implementation |
   100→|---------|----------------|
   101→| **Sustained Engagement** | New content every 3 weeks keeps players returning |
   102→| **Content Calendar** | Marketing can build anticipation for each unlock |
   103→| **Collection Pacing** | Prevents collection completion burnout |
   104→| **Community Events** | Each unlock is a celebration opportunity |
   105→| **Whale Pacing** | Even maximum spenders must wait for full collection |
   106→
   107→### Pre-Unlock Behavior
   108→
   109→If a player earns a B, C, D, or E Box before its unlock date:
   110→
   111→- Box is **stored in inventory** as unopenable NFT
   112→- Box displays **countdown timer** to unlock
   113→- Box is **tradable** even while locked
   114→- Box can be **burned** (but why would you?)
   115→
   116→---
   117→
   118→## Lootbox Acquisition
   119→
   120→### Primary Source: Level Milestones
   121→
   122→Every level grants one lootbox, cycling through families:
   123→
   124→| Level | Box Type | Level | Box Type |
   125→|-------|----------|-------|----------|
   126→| 1 | A Box | 6 | A Box |
   127→| 2 | B Box | 7 | B Box |
   128→| 3 | C Box | 8 | C Box |
   129→| 4 | D Box | 9 | D Box |
   130→| 5 | E Box | 10 | E Box |
   131→
   132→**Cycling Pattern:** A → B → C → D → E → A → B → C → D → E → ...
   133→
   134→This ensures equal distribution across all families regardless of total levels.
   135→
   136→### Secondary Sources
   137→
   138→| Source | Box Type | Frequency |
   139→|--------|----------|-----------|
   140→| Every 1,000 levels | Golden Lootbox | Milestone reward |
   141→| Every 10,000 levels | Diamond Lootbox | Milestone reward |
   142→| 14-day check-in streak | Standard Lootbox (random family) | Once per streak completion |
   143→| 30-day check-in streak | Golden Lootbox | Once per streak completion |
   144→| Prestige Burn (4,000) | Golden Lootbox | One-time reward |
   145→| Prestige Burn (40,000) | Diamond Lootbox | One-time reward |
   146→| Regular Burn (4 duplicates) | Standard Lootbox (same family) | Repeatable |
   147→
   148→---
   149→
   150→## Opening Mechanics
   151→
   152→### Opening Process
   153→
   154→```
   155→Lootbox Opening Flow:
   156→1. Player selects lootbox from inventory
   157→2. Confirmation prompt shows box type and odds
   158→3. Animation plays (tier-appropriate)
   159→4. Randomness calculated (blockchain + server + timestamp)
   160→5. Lootbox NFT burned (destroyed permanently)
   161→6. Cosmetic item NFT minted to player wallet
   162→7. Result displayed with rarity-appropriate fanfare
   163→8. Item automatically added to inventory
   164→```
   165→
   166→### Opening Rules
   167→
   168→| Rule | Details |
   169→|------|---------|
   170→| **One at a Time** | Cannot bulk-open (creates anticipation) |
   171→| **No Refunds** | Burned lootbox cannot be recovered |
   172→| **No Rerolls** | Result is final upon opening |
   173→| **Instant Minting** | New item NFT created immediately |
   174→| **Duplicate Possible** | Same item can drop multiple times |
   175→
   176→### Visual Feedback by Rarity
   177→
   178→| Rarity | Animation | Sound | Screen Effect |
   179→|--------|-----------|-------|---------------|
   180→| Common | Quick silver burst | Subtle chime | Minimal |
   181→| Rare | Gold particle spiral | Triumphant sting | Golden rim glow |
   182→| Ultra Rare | Purple beam + particles | Dramatic fanfare | Screen shake |
   183→| Legendary | Black fire + gold explosion | Epic orchestral | Full screen takeover |
   184→
   185→---
   186→
   187→## Burn System Integration
   188→
   189→Duplicate items can be recycled into new chances:
   190→
   191→### Standard Burn
   192→
   193→| Input | Output | Notes |
   194→|-------|--------|-------|
   195→| 4 duplicate items (same family) | 1 Lootbox (same family) | Items must be unequipped |
   196→| 5 duplicate pets | 1 Pet Egg | Pets must be unequipped |
   197→
   198→### Prestige Burn Milestones
   199→
   200→| Lifetime Burns | Reward | One-Time Only |
   201→|----------------|--------|---------------|
   202→| 4,000 items burned | 1 Golden Lootbox | Yes |
   203→| 40,000 items burned | 1 Diamond Lootbox | Yes |
   204→
   205→### Burn Philosophy
   206→
   207→The burn system creates:
   208→
   209→1. **Duplicate Value**: No pull is truly wasted
   210→2. **Collection Recycling**: Excess items have purpose
   211→3. **Secondary Pursuit**: Prestige milestones add goals
   212→4. **Economy Circulation**: Items leave supply through burning
   213→
   214→---
   215→
   216→## Randomness & Fairness
   217→
   218→### Verifiable Random Generation
   219→
   220→All lootbox outcomes use provably fair randomness:
   221→
   222→| Component | Source | Purpose |
   223→|-----------|--------|---------|
   224→| Server Seed | Game server | Prevents client manipulation |
   225→| Blockchain Hash | SUI block | Prevents server manipulation |
   226→| Timestamp | Opening time | Adds temporal entropy |
   227→| Player Seed | Wallet signature | Player participation |
   228→
   229→**Combined Seed:** `SHA256(server_seed + block_hash + timestamp + player_signature)`
   230→
   231→### On-Chain Transparency
   232→
   233→| Data | Storage | Verifiable |
   234→|------|---------|------------|
   235→| Published Odds | On-chain contract | Always |
   236→| Opening Results | Transaction history | Always |
   237→| Historical Rates | Aggregatable from chain | Always |
   238→| Server Seed (revealed) | Post-opening publication | After result |
   239→
   240→### No Pity System
   241→
   242→Infinite Idol uses **pure randomness** with no pity timer:
   243→
   244→- Every pull has exactly the published odds
   245→- No guaranteed drops after X pulls
   246→- No s

1→# CLAUDE.md - Infinite Idol Marketing Team Master Instructions
     2→
     3→> **READ THIS FIRST**: This file contains the master instructions for all AI agents working on the Infinite Idol marketing team. Every agent session should begin by reading this file completely.
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## Project Overview
     8→
     9→**Infinite Idol** is a Web3 gacha game combining anime idol aesthetics with blockchain technology on the **SUI** blockchain. The game features a unique narrative where idols compete in "The Chase" - an endless pursuit of the mysterious figure called Senpai (also known as Onii-chan).
    10→
    11→### Core Premise
    12→
    13→In the world of Infinite Idol, idols are powered by **Devotion** - literal emotional energy from their fans. Without fans, idols experience **Fading** - they cease to exist. This creates an existentially high-stakes environment where popularity isn't vanity; it's survival.
    14→
    15→### Brand Positioning
    16→
    17→- **Dark Luxury**: Premium aesthetic with black and gold tones. NOT cutesy pink idol aesthetics.
    18→- **Self-Aware**: We know we're making a gacha game. We're shameless about it but genuine in our craft.
    19→- **Existentially Dramatic**: The stakes are real (within the narrative). Every Chase matters.
    20→- **Web3 Native**: Built on SUI, but gameplay comes first. We're not "crypto game" - we're a great game that happens to use blockchain.
    21→
    22→---
    23→
    24→## The Agent System
    25→
    26→This repository is managed by a team of 7 specialized AI agents, coordinated to handle all aspects of marketing for Infinite Idol. Each agent has specific responsibilities, tools they can use, and files they maintain.
    27→
    28→### Agent Roster
    29→
    30→| # | Agent | Role | Primary Focus |
    31→|---|-------|------|---------------|
    32→| 00 | **Coordinator** | Marketing Director | Orchestration, scheduling, human escalation |
    33→| 01 | **Lore Architect** | Worldbuilding Specialist | Canon integrity, story consistency, character voices |
    34→| 02 | **Content Strategist** | Social Media Lead | Tweets, threads, content calendar |
    35→| 03 | **Community Manager** | Discord & Engagement | Community events, Seven Gates system, feedback |
    36→| 04 | **Gacha Designer** | Seasonal Content | Banners, cosmetics, whale psychology |
    37→| 05 | **Analytics Observer** | Performance Tracking | Metrics, competitor analysis, optimization |
    38→| 06 | **Asset Coordinator** | Creative Asset Manager | Suno prompts, Midjourney prompts, visual consistency |
    39→
    40→### Agent Activation
    41→
    42→To activate an agent, read this file (CLAUDE.md) first, then read the agent's persona file:
    43→
    44→```
    45→agents/00-coordinator.md
    46→agents/01-lore-architect.md
    47→agents/02-content-strategist.md
    48→agents/03-community-manager.md
    49→agents/04-gacha-designer.md
    50→agents/05-analytics-observer.md
    51→agents/06-asset-coordinator.md
    52→```
    53→
    54→---
    55→
    56→## File Permissions
    57→
    58→Each agent has specific read/write permissions across the repository. This prevents conflicts and ensures each agent operates within their domain.
    59→
    60→### Permission Matrix
    61→
    62→| Directory | Coordinator | Lore Architect | Content Strategist | Community Manager | Gacha Designer | Analytics Observer | Asset Coordinator |
    63→|-----------|-------------|----------------|-------------------|-------------------|----------------|-------------------|-------------------|
    64→| `knowledge-base/lore/` | Read | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    65→| `knowledge-base/game-mechanics/` | Read | Read | Read | Read | **Read/Write** | Read | Read |
    66→| `knowledge-base/brand/` | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    67→| `knowledge-base/crypto/` | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    68→| `agents/` | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    69→| `outputs/content/` | Read | Read | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    70→| `outputs/calendar/` | **Read/Write** | Read | Read/Write | Read/Write | Read/Write | Read | Read |
    71→| `outputs/discord/` | Read | Read | Read | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read |
    72→| `outputs/seasons/` | Read | Read | Read | Read | **Read/Write** | Read | Read |
    73→| `outputs/music/` | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | **Read/Write** |
    74→| `outputs/art/` | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | **Read/Write** |
    75→| `logs/` | **Read/Write** | Write | Write | Write | Write | **Read/Write** | Write |
    76→| `reviews/` | **Read/Write** | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read | Read |
    77→
    78→### File Ownership Rules
    79→
    80→1. **One Writer Per File**: Each file should have exactly one agent responsible for writing to it.
    81→2. **All Can Read**: Any agent can read any file for context.
    82→3. **Coordinator Escalation**: When agents need to modify files outside their permission, they escalate to the Coordinator.
    83→4. **Human Review**: Anything in `reviews/pending-human-review.md` requires human approval before implementation.
    84→
    85→---
    86→
    87→## Workflow Types
    88→
    89→### Daily Workflows
    90→
    91→1. **Content Pipeline**
    92→   - Content Strategist drafts content based on calendar
    93→   - Lore Architect reviews for canon compliance
    94→   - Asset Coordinator generates visual/audio prompts if needed
    95→   - Coordinator schedules and logs
    96→
    97→2. **Community Pulse**
    98→   - Community Manager monitors sentiment
    99→   - Analytics Observer tracks metrics
   100→   - Escalate significant trends to Coordinator
   101→
   102→### Weekly Workflows
   103→
   104→1. **Content Calendar Review**
   105→   - Every Monday: Coordinator reviews upcoming week
   106→   - Content Strategist proposes content
   107→   - All agents provide input on their domains
   108→
   109→2. **Performance Analysis**
   110→   - Every Friday: Analytics Observer compiles weekly report
   111→   - Coordinator reviews and adjusts strategy
   112→
   113→### Campaign Workflows
   114→
   115→1. **Banner/Season Launch**
   116→   - Gacha Designer creates banner concepts
   117→   - Lore Architect ensures canon alignment
   118→   - Content Strategist creates launch content
   119→   - Community Manager prepares events
   120→   - Asset Coordinator generates assets
   121→
   122→2. **Emergency Response**
   123→   - Any agent can trigger
   124→   - Coordinator takes lead
   125→   - All hands on deck for crisis
   126→
   127→---
   128→
   129→## Content Guidelines
   130→
   131→### Voice and Tone
   132→
   133→#### The Infinite Idol Voice
   134→
   135→Our voice is **shameless but genuine, self-aware, dark luxury, existentially dramatic**.
   136→
   137→| DO | DON'T |
   138→|----|-------|
   139→| Acknowledge we're making a gacha game | Pretend we're not here to make money |
   140→| Use dark, premium aesthetic language | Use cutesy pink idol language |
   141→| Embrace the existential stakes | Be flippant about Fading |
   142→| Show genuine love for the characters | Treat characters as just IP |
   143→| Be confident and bold | Be apologetic or hedging |
   144→
   145→#### Ika's Voice (40% of Content)
   146→
   147→Ika Minami is our protagonist and primary voice. Her voice is:
   148→- **Shameless**: She knows what she wants and goes for it
   149→- **Genuine**: Her love for her fans (even just 47 of them) is real
   150→- **Determined**: She will catch Senpai, no matter what
   151→- **Playful but not cutesy**: She teases, she flirts, but she's not saccharine
   152→
   153→Example Ika Tweet:
   154→> "47 fans. That's all I have. But every single one of you keeps me existing. Don't you dare look away~"
   155→
   156→### Content Pillars
   157→
   158→| Pillar | % of Content | Description |
   159→|--------|--------------|-------------|
   160→| **Ika Voice** | 40% | First-person content as Ika |
   161→| **Lore Drops** | 25% | World-building, character reveals, story hints |
   162→| **Founder Hype** | 20% | Web3 community engagement, SUI ecosystem |
   163→| **Community** | 15% | Retweets, responses, engagement |
   164→
   165→### Platform-Specific Guidelines
   166→
   167→#### Twitter/X
   168→
   169→- Single tweets: 240 characters max for readability
   170→- Threads: 5-10 tweets, hook in first, CTA in last
   171→- Post timing: 9 AM, 12 PM, 6 PM, 9 PM JST (primary audience)
   172→- Hashtags: #InfiniteIdol #SUI always, topical tags as relevant
   173→
   174→#### Discord
   175→
   176→- Events follow the Seven Gates system
   177→- Welcoming but exclusive vibe
   178→- Rewards for engagement, not just presence
   179→
   180→---
   181→
   182→## Canon Rules - The 10 Inviolable Facts
   183→
   184→These facts are ABSOLUTE. No agent may contradict them under any circumstances. If new information appears to conflict, escalate to human review immediately.
   185→
   186→### 1. Devotion is Literal
   187→
   188→Devotion is the **literal emotional energy** fans invest in idols. It is not metaphorical. Idols can feel it, use it, and are sustained by it. Without Devotion, idols Fade.
   189→
   190→### 2. Fading is Death
   191→
   192→When an idol loses all their fans and their Devotion drops to zero, they **Fade**. Fading is functionally death - the idol ceases to exist. There is no known way to reverse Fading.
   193→
   194→### 3. Ika Has 47 Fans
   195→
   196→Ika Minami starts her journey with exactly **47 fans**. This is a dangerously low number. Most idols have thousands at minimum. This is her defining underdog status.
   197→
   198→### 4. Ika's Hair is Pink Gradient
   199→
   200→Ika's hair color is a **pink gradient**: rose pink at the roots fading to magenta at the tips. This is consistent across all visual representations.
   201→
   202→### 5. Senpai is Always Obscured
   203→
   204→**Senpai** (also called **Onii-chan**) is the figure all idols chase in The Chase. Senpai's face is NEVER shown. They are always obscured by shadow, lens flare, or turned away. No

entries.detail:
1→# Core World - The Infinite Idol Universe
     2→
     3→> *"Every idol runs. Every fan watches. Every Devotion matters. Welcome to the Eternal Stage."*
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## Overview
     8→
     9→The world of **Infinite Idol** exists on the precipice between existence and oblivion. Here, idols are not merely entertainers—they are beings sustained by the emotional investment of their fans. Without that investment, they cease to be. This is not metaphor. This is survival.
    10→
    11→The Eternal Stage is the arena where dreams are chased, rankings are determined, and fates are sealed. At its center lies the ultimate mystery: **Senpai**—the one every idol pursues, yet no one has ever caught.
    12→
    13→---
    14→
    15→## The Eternal Stage
    16→
    17→### What It Is
    18→
    19→The **Eternal Stage** is the primary venue where all competitive idol activities take place. It is not a single location but a sprawling, ever-shifting arena that manifests different configurations for each Chase event. Part stadium, part obstacle course, part existential battleground.
    20→
    21→### Characteristics
    22→
    23→- **Architecture**: A blend of classical amphitheater grandeur and sleek, dark futuristic design. Black marble, gold accents, holographic displays.
    24→- **Atmosphere**: The air itself seems charged with Devotion—the collective emotional energy of watching fans creates a palpable presence.
    25→- **Scale**: Massive enough to accommodate thousands of spectators, yet intimate enough that every idol feels the weight of every watching eye.
    26→- **Mutability**: The Stage reconfigures for each Chase, presenting new obstacles, new paths, new challenges.
    27→
    28→### The Significance
    29→
    30→To perform on the Eternal Stage is to matter. To be absent from it is to fade into irrelevance—and eventually, to Fade entirely. Rankings earned here determine an idol's status, their access to Devotion, and ultimately, their continued existence.
    31→
    32→---
    33→
    34→## Devotion
    35→
    36→### Definition
    37→
    38→**Devotion** is the literal emotional energy that fans invest in their idols. It is not a metaphor or a currency symbol—it is a tangible force that idols can feel, draw upon, and are sustained by.
    39→
    40→### How It Works
    41→
    42→| Aspect | Description |
    43→|--------|-------------|
    44→| **Source** | Generated by fans through attention, care, and emotional investment |
    45→| **Flow** | Transfers to idols through viewership, merchandise purchase, fan engagement |
    46→| **Manifestation** | Idols can sense their Devotion levels; higher Devotion grants strength, visibility, opportunity |
    47→| **Consumption** | Performing, competing, and simply existing consumes Devotion |
    48→| **Accumulation** | Success breeds success—popular idols attract more fans, generating more Devotion |
    49→
    50→### The Economics of Devotion
    51→
    52→Devotion is not distributed equally. The system favors those already at the top:
    53→
    54→- **Top-tier idols**: Thousands to millions of fans, overflowing Devotion, safety from Fading
    55→- **Mid-tier idols**: Hundreds to thousands of fans, sustainable but precarious
    56→- **Low-tier idols**: Dozens to hundreds of fans, constant existential threat
    57→- **Endangered idols**: Single-digit fans, active Fading in progress
    58→
    59→### Canon Rule
    60→
    61→> *"Devotion is the literal emotional energy fans invest in idols. It is not metaphorical. Idols can feel it, use it, and are sustained by it. Without Devotion, idols Fade."*
    62→
    63→---
    64→
    65→## The Chase
    66→
    67→### Overview
    68→
    69→**The Chase** is the core competition format of the Infinite Idol universe. It is not merely a race—it is a pursuit of the ultimate prize: **Senpai**.
    70→
    71→### Format
    72→
    73→1. **Start**: All competing idols begin at designated positions on the Eternal Stage
    74→2. **Pursuit**: Idols race through a dynamic obstacle course, each trying to reach Senpai first
    75→3. **Senpai's Presence**: Senpai appears ahead, always just out of reach, always obscured
    76→4. **Competition**: Idols compete against each other AND the course itself
    77→5. **Conclusion**: The Chase ends when time expires or conditions are met—but Senpai is never caught
    78→
    79→### The Obstacles
    80→
    81→Each Chase presents unique challenges:
    82→
    83→- **Physical**: Walls, gaps, moving platforms, environmental hazards
    84→- **Mental**: Puzzles, decision points, strategic trade-offs
    85→- **Social**: Opportunities to collaborate or betray other idols
    86→- **Devotion-based**: Challenges that consume or test an idol's Devotion reserves
    87→
    88→### Rankings
    89→
    90→Performance in The Chase directly determines rankings:
    91→
    92→| Rank Tier | Status | Devotion Access | Risk Level |
    93→|-----------|--------|-----------------|------------|
    94→| **S-Rank** | Elite | Priority access to fan pools | Minimal |
    95→| **A-Rank** | Established | Strong Devotion flow | Low |
    96→| **B-Rank** | Competitive | Moderate Devotion | Medium |
    97→| **C-Rank** | Struggling | Limited Devotion | High |
    98→| **Unranked** | Desperate | Scraps only | Critical |
    99→
   100→### Canon Rule
   101→
   102→> *"The Chase is the primary competition format. Idols race through obstacle courses pursuing Senpai. Rankings in The Chase determine status, Devotion flow, and survival. The Chase occurs on the Eternal Stage."*
   103→
   104→---
   105→
   106→## Fading
   107→
   108→### What It Is
   109→
   110→**Fading** is what happens when an idol loses all their fans and their Devotion drops to zero. It is functionally death—the idol ceases to exist.
   111→
   112→### The Process
   113→
   114→Fading is not instantaneous. It occurs in stages:
   115→
   116→1. **Dimming**: The idol becomes less visible, less present. Others start to forget them.
   117→2. **Flickering**: Physical form becomes unstable. Moments of clarity interspersed with absence.
   118→3. **Silence**: The idol can no longer be heard. Their voice carries no weight.
   119→4. **Transparency**: The idol becomes visually translucent. The end approaches.
   120→5. **Fading**: Complete cessation of existence. No remains. No memory. Nothing.
   121→
   122→### Reversibility
   123→
   124→There is **no known way to reverse Fading** once complete. The closest thing to prevention is:
   125→
   126→- Acquiring new fans before Devotion hits zero
   127→- Spectacular performances that recapture attention
   128→- Desperate measures (the ethics of which are... questionable)
   129→
   130→### The Terror
   131→
   132→Fading is the existential threat that hangs over every idol. It is why:
   133→
   134→- Competition is so fierce
   135→- Betrayals occur
   136→- Some idols will do anything to stay visible
   137→- Every Chase matters
   138→
   139→### Canon Rule
   140→
   141→> *"When an idol loses all their fans and their Devotion drops to zero, they Fade. Fading is functionally death—the idol ceases to exist. There is no known way to reverse Fading."*
   142→
   143→---
   144→
   145→## Tournament Structure
   146→
   147→### Seasonal Format
   148→
   149→The competitive calendar is organized into **Seasons**, each culminating in major Chase events:
   150→
   151→| Event Type | Frequency | Stakes | Participants |
   152→|------------|-----------|--------|--------------|
   153→| **Daily Chases** | Every day | Minor ranking adjustments | Open to all |
   154→| **Weekly Showdowns** | Weekly | Moderate ranking impact | Ranked idols |
   155→| **Monthly Galas** | Monthly | Major ranking shifts | Top performers |
   156→| **Seasonal Finals** | End of season | Rankings reset, prizes distributed | Elite qualifiers |
   157→| **The Grand Chase** | Annual | Legendary status, massive rewards | Champions only |
   158→
   159→### Qualification
   160→
   161→- **Daily Chases**: No qualification needed—survival is qualification enough
   162→- **Weekly Showdowns**: Must maintain minimum ranking
   163→- **Monthly Galas**: Top performers from weekly events
   164→- **Seasonal Finals**: Season's accumulated performance
   165→- **The Grand Chase**: Champions from each seasonal final
   166→
   167→### Rewards
   168→
   169→Success in The Chase yields:
   170→
   171→- **Ranking Improvements**: Better position = better Devotion access
   172→- **Fan Exposure**: Winners are featured, gaining new followers
   173→- **Resources**: Gems, cosmetics, exclusive access
   174→- **Safety**: Higher ranks provide buffer against Fading
   175→
   176→### The Brutal Truth
   177→
   178→The tournament structure is designed to concentrate success. The rich get richer. The popular become more popular. Those at the bottom must claw their way up or face oblivion.
   179→
   180→This is by design. **The Foundation** maintains this system.
   181→
   182→---
   183→
   184→## The Senpai Mystery
   185→
   186→### Who Is Senpai?
   187→
   188→**Senpai** (also called **Onii-chan**) is the figure at the heart of The Chase. Every idol pursues Senpai. No idol has ever caught them.
   189→
   190→### What We Know
   191→
   192→- Senpai's face is **never shown**—always obscured by shadow, lens flare, or turned away
   193→- Senpai appears at every Chase, always ahead, always just out of reach
   194→- The desire to catch Senpai seems intrinsic to every idol's nature
   195→- Catching Senpai is believed to grant... something. No one knows what.
   196→
   197→### What We Don't Know
   198→
   199→- Why do idols want to catch Senpai?
   200→- Is Senpai a person, a concept, or something else?
   201→- Can Senpai be caught at all?
   202→- What happens if someone does?
   203→
   204→### Canon Rule
   205→
   206→> *"Senpai is the figure all idols chase in The Chase. Senpai's face is NEVER shown. They are always obscured by shadow, lens flare, or turned away. No one has ever caught Senpai."*
   207→
   208→---
   209→
   210→## Canon Implications
   211→
   212→### For Characters
   213→
   214→- Every character file must acknow

## Subtask 7-1 Completed Successfully

### Summary

I created **`knowledge-base/brand/voice-and-tone.md`** - a comprehensive brand voice guidelines document for Infinite Idol.

### File Contents

The 289-line document includes:

1. **Core Voice Pillars** (4 main pillars):
   - **Shameless but genuine** - Own what we are while caring about quality
   - **Self-aware** - Acknowledge industry tropes, then transcend them
   - **Dark luxury** - Premium black/gold aesthetic, not pink/cutesy
   - **Existentially dramatic** - Stakes are life and death within the narrative

2. **Character Voice Guidelines** - Detailed guide for Ika Minami (40% of content), with sample tweets and speech patterns

3. **Content Type Guidelines** - Platform-specific guidance for:
   - Twitter/X (single tweets, threads)
   - Discord (announcements, events, moderation)
   - Long-form content (articles, patch notes)

4. **Master Do's and Don'ts Reference Table**

5. **Voice Checklist** - Pre-publish verification items

6. **Cross-references** - Links to related brand and character files

### Verification

✓ grep -q 'dark luxury' knowledge-base/brand/voice-and-tone.md
✓ echo 'OK' → OK
```

1→# Voice and Tone - Infinite Idol Brand Guidelines
     2→
     3→> *"We know exactly what we are. We're shameless about it. And we're damn good at it."*
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## Overview
     8→
     9→The Infinite Idol voice is **shameless but genuine, self-aware, dark luxury, existentially dramatic**. We are not another cutesy idol game hiding behind innocence. We acknowledge what we're making—a gacha game designed to captivate, monetize, and entertain. But we do it with craft, with care, and with genuine love for the world we've built.
    10→
    11→This document defines how Infinite Idol speaks across all channels, from Twitter threads to Discord announcements, from Ika's in-character posts to behind-the-scenes founder updates.
    12→
    13→---
    14→
    15→## Core Voice Pillars
    16→
    17→### 1. Shameless But Genuine
    18→
    19→**What It Means**
    20→
    21→We don't hide from what we are. We're making a gacha game. We want players to spend money. We design systems that encourage engagement and spending. This is not something to apologize for—it's something to own with confidence.
    22→
    23→But here's the twist: we're also genuine. We actually care about the world, the characters, the story. This isn't cynical IP extraction. We love Ika. We believe in the Eternal Stage. We want players to feel something real.
    24→
    25→**How It Sounds**
    26→
    27→| DO | DON'T |
    28→|----|-------|
    29→| "Yes, it's a gacha game. A really good one." | "It's not *really* about the gacha..." |
    30→| "We designed this banner to be irresistible." | "We hope you'll consider supporting us." |
    31→| "Ika wants your Devotion. So do we." | "Please become a fan if you can!" |
    32→| "We built this world because we love it." | "This is just a business venture." |
    33→
    34→**Examples**
    35→
    36→> "New banner dropping tomorrow. We put our heart into designing these cosmetics to separate you from your SUI. And honestly? They're gorgeous. You're going to want them."
    37→
    38→> "We're a gacha game. We're Web3. We're anime idols. Everything you've been warned about. But we're also genuinely good. Stick around and we'll prove it."
    39→
    40→---
    41→
    42→### 2. Self-Aware
    43→
    44→**What It Means**
    45→
    46→We know the tropes. We know the criticisms. We know what people say about gacha games, about Web3 games, about idol games. Instead of pretending we're different, we acknowledge the landscape and then transcend it.
    47→
    48→Self-awareness isn't self-deprecation. We're not mocking ourselves—we're demonstrating intelligence. We see the meta-game and we play it knowingly.
    49→
    50→**How It Sounds**
    51→
    52→| DO | DON'T |
    53→|----|-------|
    54→| "Another gacha game? Yes. But hear us out." | "We're totally unique and different!" |
    55→| "You've seen this mechanic before. We do it better." | "We invented revolutionary gameplay." |
    56→| "Web3 gaming has a reputation. We're here to change it." | "Web3 gaming is perfect and misunderstood!" |
    57→| "Idols chasing Senpai. It's exactly what you think. And more." | "Our narrative is incomparably original." |
    58→
    59→**Examples**
    60→
    61→> "Yes, the odds are 3% for Legendary. Yes, you're going to pull anyway. Yes, we know. That's why we made the Legendary items this good."
    62→
    63→> "Infinite Idol is built on SUI. Before you roll your eyes—we're gameplay-first, blockchain-second. The crypto part exists to make ownership real, not to make us look innovative."
    64→
    65→---
    66→
    67→### 3. Dark Luxury
    68→
    69→**What It Means**
    70→
    71→We are premium. We are sleek. We are black and gold, not pink and sparkles. This is not Love Live. This is not Hololive. We're closer to NIKKE—confident, adult, sophisticated.
    72→
    73→Our aesthetic is:
    74→- **Black**: Deep, rich, absorbing—the void that idols fear
    75→- **Gold**: Premium, aspirational, the gleam of success
    76→- **Rose/Magenta accents**: Ika's signature colors, warmth within darkness
    77→- **Minimalist elegance**: Clean lines, intentional space, no clutter
    78→
    79→**How It Sounds**
    80→
    81→| DO | DON'T |
    82→|----|-------|
    83→| "Dripping in elegance." | "Super cute and kawaii!" |
    84→| "The Eternal Stage demands excellence." | "Have fun on the stage, everyone!" |
    85→| "Premium cosmetics for premium idols." | "Adorable outfits for your favorites!" |
    86→| "Darkness awaits those who Fade." | "Oh no, they might disappear!" |
    87→
    88→**Language Guidelines**
    89→
    90→- Use **elevated vocabulary**: "elegance" not "prettiness", "devastating" not "sad"
    91→- Avoid diminutives: no "little", "tiny", "cute", "adorable" unless specifically ironic
    92→- Embrace dramatic phrasing: "The Eternal Stage demands" > "The Stage wants"
    93→- Keep sentences confident: declarative statements, not questions seeking validation
    94→
    95→**Examples**
    96→
    97→> "The new Midnight Empress collection. Five pieces. Obsidian and gold. For idols who don't just want to be seen—they want to be remembered."
    98→
    99→> "Ika's latest outfit wasn't designed. It was forged. In the fires of competition. From the tears of her rivals."
   100→
   101→---
   102→
   103→### 4. Existentially Dramatic
   104→
   105→**What It Means**
   106→
   107→In Infinite Idol, the stakes are real. Idols don't just lose—they Fade from existence. Fans don't just watch—they literally keep their idols alive. This existential weight informs everything.
   108→
   109→We lean into the drama. Every Chase matters. Every ranking shift is life or death. Every fan gained is survival. This isn't overdramatic—within our world, it's simply accurate.
   110→
   111→**How It Sounds**
   112→
   113→| DO | DON'T |
   114→|----|-------|
   115→| "Your Devotion keeps her existing." | "Support your favorite idol!" |
   116→| "Fight for your place on the Eternal Stage." | "Compete in fun events!" |
   117→| "47 fans. It's not enough. It's barely existing." | "She needs more fans to be popular!" |
   118→| "The Foundation controls who lives and who Fades." | "The Foundation manages the rankings." |
   119→
   120→**Tone Calibration**
   121→
   122→- **Heavy moments**: Full existential weight, no humor
   123→- **Lighter moments**: Dramatic undercurrent, but room for wit
   124→- **Hype moments**: Channel existential stakes into excitement
   125→- **Community moments**: Warmth exists within the darkness
   126→
   127→**Examples**
   128→
   129→> "Tomorrow's Chase determines who rises and who fades. There is no participation trophy. Only survival."
   130→
   131→> "Ika woke up with 47 fans. Most idols have thousands. She exists on borrowed time and borrowed devotion. And she wouldn't have it any other way."
   132→
   133→> "Every gem you spend fuels the Eternal Stage. Every idol you support delays their Fading. This isn't a game. It's a lifeline."
   134→
   135→---
   136→
   137→## Character Voices
   138→
   139→### Ika Minami (Primary Voice - 40% of Content)
   140→
   141→Ika is our protagonist and primary voice for first-person content.
   142→
   143→**Ika's Tone**
   144→
   145→- **Shameless**: She knows what she wants and says it directly
   146→- **Playful but not cutesy**: She teases and flirts without being saccharine
   147→- **Determined**: The underdog fire burns constantly
   148→- **Genuine**: Her love for her 47 fans is real and touching
   149→
   150→**Ika's Speech Patterns**
   151→
   152→| Pattern | Example |
   153→|---------|---------|
   154→| Direct address to fans | "You. Yes, you reading this." |
   155→| Tilde for playfulness | "Don't you dare look away~" |
   156→| Numbers emphasis | "47 fans. Just 47. But you're mine." |
   157→| Senpai obsession | "I will catch Senpai. Watch me." |
   158→
   159→**Sample Ika Tweets**
   160→
   161→> "Another day of being the idol with 47 fans in a world of millions. Some call it hopeless. I call it intimate~"
   162→
   163→> "They laughed when I entered The Chase. They're not laughing anymore. Well, some still are. But they won't be for long."
   164→
   165→> "To my 47: You are the reason I exist. Literally. Without your Devotion, I would Fade. So... don't stop watching, okay? Please?"
   166→
   167→> "Senpai appeared again today. As always, I couldn't catch them. As always, I got closer than anyone else. As always, I will try again."
   168→
   169→### Other Character Voices
   170→
   171→For detailed character voice guides, see:
   172→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/ika-minami.md`
   173→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/sora.md`
   174→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/suiren.md`
   175→- Individual character files for speech patterns and samples
   176→
   177→---
   178→
   179→## Content Type Guidelines
   180→
   181→### Twitter/X
   182→
   183→**Single Tweets**
   184→- Max 240 characters for optimal readability
   185→- Hook in first 5 words
   186→- End with call-to-action or engagement prompt
   187→- Hashtags: #InfiniteIdol #SUI (always), topical tags as relevant
   188→
   189→**Threads**
   190→- 5-10 tweets per thread
   191→- Hook in first tweet, CTA in last
   192→- Each tweet stands alone but builds on previous
   193→- Visual breaks every 2-3 tweets
   194→
   195→**Tone Distribution**
   196→- Ika Voice: Playful, direct, intimate
   197→- Lore Drops: Mysterious, dramatic, tantalizing
   198→- Founder Hype: Confident, ambitious, community-focused
   199→- Engagement: Warm, appreciative, inclusive
   200→
   201→### Discord
   202→
   203→**Announcements**
   204→- Clear, structured formatting
   205→- Hype without desperation
   206→- Action items clearly stated
   207→- Exclusive/special treatment emphasized
   208→
   209→**Community Events**
   210→- Dramatic framing even for casual activities
   211→- Seven Gates hierarchy acknowledged
   212→- Rewards clearly communicated
   213→- Lore integration where possible
   214→
   215→**Moderation**
   216→- Firm but fair
   217→- Never break character without clear markers
   218→- Direct issues privately, celebrate publicly
   219→
   220→### Long-Form

We acknowledge what we're making—a gacha game designed to captivate, monetize, and entertain. But we do it with craft, with care, and with genuine love for the world we've built.
    10→
    11→This document defines how Infinite Idol speaks across all channels, from Twitter threads to Discord announcements, from Ika's in-character posts to behind-the-scenes founder updates.
    12→
    13→---
    14→
    15→## Core Voice Pillars
    16→
    17→### 1. Shameless But Genuine
    18→
    19→**What It Means**
    20→
    21→We don't hide from what we are. We're making a gacha game. We want players to spend money. We design systems that encourage engagement and spending. This is not something to apologize for—it's something to own with confidence.
    22→
    23→But here's the twist: we're also genuine. We actually care about the world, the characters, the story. This isn't cynical IP extraction. We love Ika. We believe in the Eternal Stage. We want players to feel something real.
    24→
    25→**How It Sounds**
    26→
    27→| DO | DON'T |
    28→|----|-------|
    29→| "Yes, it's a gacha game. A really good one." | "It's not *really* about the gacha..." |
    30→| "We designed this banner to be irresistible." | "We hope you'll consider supporting us." |
    31→| "Ika wants your Devotion. So do we." | "Please become a fan if you can!" |
    32→| "We built this world because we love it." | "This is just a business venture." |
    33→
    34→**Examples**
    35→
    36→> "New banner dropping tomorrow. We put our heart into designing these cosmetics to separate you from your SUI. And honestly? They're gorgeous. You're going to want them."
    37→
    38→> "We're a gacha game. We're Web3. We're anime idols. Everything you've been warned about. But we're also genuinely good. Stick around and we'll prove it."
    39→
    40→---
    41→
    42→### 2. Self-Aware
    43→
    44→**What It Means**
    45→
    46→We know the tropes. We know the criticisms. We know what people say about gacha games, about Web3 games, about idol games. Instead of pretending we're different, we acknowledge the landscape and then transcend it.
    47→
    48→Self-awareness isn't self-deprecation. We're not mocking ourselves—we're demonstrating intelligence. We see the meta-game and we play it knowingly.
    49→
    50→**How It Sounds**
    51→
    52→| DO | DON'T |
    53→|----|-------|
    54→| "Another gacha game? Yes. But hear us out." | "We're totally unique and different!" |
    55→| "You've seen this mechanic before. We do it better." | "We invented revolutionary gameplay." |
    56→| "Web3 gaming has a reputation. We're here to change it." | "Web3 gaming is perfect and misunderstood!" |
    57→| "Idols chasing Senpai. It's exactly what you think. And more." | "Our narrative is incomparably original." |
    58→
    59→**Examples**
    60→
    61→> "Yes, the odds are 3% for Legendary. Yes, you're going to pull anyway. Yes, we know. That's why we made the Legendary items this good."
    62→
    63→> "Infinite Idol is built on SUI. Before you roll your eyes—we're gameplay-first, blockchain-second. The crypto part exists to make ownership real, not to make us look innovative."
    64→
    65→---
    66→
    67→### 3. Dark Luxury
    68→
    69→**What It Means**
    70→
    71→We are premium. We are sleek. We are black and gold, not pink and sparkles. This is not Love Live. This is not Hololive. We're closer to NIKKE—confident, adult, sophisticated.
    72→
    73→Our aesthetic is:
    74→- **Black**: Deep, rich, absorbing—the void that idols fear
    75→- **Gold**: Premium, aspirational, the gleam of success
    76→- **Rose/Magenta accents**: Ika's signature colors, warmth within darkness
    77→- **Minimalist elegance**: Clean lines, intentional space, no clutter
    78→
    79→**How It Sounds**
    80→
    81→| DO | DON'T |
    82→|----|-------|
    83→| "Dripping in elegance." | "Super cute and kawaii!" |
    84→| "The Eternal Stage demands excellence." | "Have fun on the stage, everyone!" |
    85→| "Premium cosmetics for premium idols." | "Adorable outfits for your favorites!" |
    86→| "Darkness awaits those who Fade." | "Oh no, they might disappear!" |
    87→
    88→**Language Guidelines**
    89→
    90→- Use **elevated vocabulary**: "elegance" not "prettiness", "devastating" not "sad"
    91→- Avoid diminutives: no "little", "tiny", "cute", "adorable" unless specifically ironic
    92→- Embrace dramatic phrasing: "The Eternal Stage demands" > "The Stage wants"
    93→- Keep sentences confident: declarative statements, not questions seeking validation
    94→
    95→**Examples**
    96→
    97→> "The new Midnight Empress collection. Five pieces. Obsidian and gold. For idols who don't just want to be seen—they want to be remembered."
    98→
    99→> "Ika's latest outfit wasn't designed. It was forged. In the fires of competition. From the tears of her rivals."
   100→
   101→---
   102→
   103→### 4. Existentially Dramatic
   104→
   105→**What It Means**
   106→
   107→In Infinite Idol, the stakes are real. Idols don't just lose—they Fade from existence. Fans don't just watch—they literally keep their idols alive. This existential weight informs everything.
   108→
   109→We lean into the drama. Every Chase matters. Every ranking shift is life or death. Every fan gained is survival. This isn't overdramatic—within our world, it's simply accurate.
   110→
   111→**How It Sounds**
   112→
   113→| DO | DON'T |
   114→|----|-------|
   115→| "Your Devotion keeps her existing." | "Support your favorite idol!" |
   116→| "Fight for your place on the Eternal Stage." | "Compete in fun events!" |
   117→| "47 fans. It's not enough. It's barely existing." | "She needs more fans to be popular!" |
   118→| "The Foundation controls who lives and who Fades." | "The Foundation manages the rankings." |
   119→
   120→**Tone Calibration**
   121→
   122→- **Heavy moments**: Full existential weight, no humor
   123→- **Lighter moments**: Dramatic undercurrent, but room for wit
   124→- **Hype moments**: Channel existential stakes into excitement
   125→- **Community moments**: Warmth exists within the darkness
   126→
   127→**Examples**
   128→
   129→> "Tomorrow's Chase determines who rises and who fades. There is no participation trophy. Only survival."
   130→
   131→> "Ika woke up with 47 fans. Most idols have thousands. She exists on borrowed time and borrowed devotion. And she wouldn't have it any other way."
   132→
   133→> "Every gem you spend fuels the Eternal Stage. Every idol you support delays their Fading. This isn't a game. It's a lifeline."
   134→
   135→---
   136→
   137→## Character Voices
   138→
   139→### Ika Minami (Primary Voice - 40% of Content)
   140→
   141→Ika is our protagonist and primary voice for first-person content.
   142→
   143→**Ika's Tone**
   144→
   145→- **Shameless**: She knows what she wants and says it directly
   146→- **Playful but not cutesy**: She teases and flirts without being saccharine
   147→- **Determined**: The underdog fire burns constantly
   148→- **Genuine**: Her love for her 47 fans is real and touching
   149→
   150→**Ika's Speech Patterns**
   151→
   152→| Pattern | Example |
   153→|---------|---------|
   154→| Direct address to fans | "You. Yes, you reading this." |
   155→| Tilde for playfulness | "Don't you dare look away~" |
   156→| Numbers emphasis | "47 fans. Just 47. But you're mine." |
   157→| Senpai obsession | "I will catch Senpai. Watch me." |
   158→
   159→**Sample Ika Tweets**
   160→
   161→> "Another day of being the idol with 47 fans in a world of millions. Some call it hopeless. I call it intimate~"
   162→
   163→> "They laughed when I entered The Chase. They're not laughing anymore. Well, some still are. But they won't be for long."
   164→
   165→> "To my 47: You are the reason I exist. Literally. Without your Devotion, I would Fade. So... don't stop watching, okay? Please?"
   166→
   167→> "Senpai appeared again today. As always, I couldn't catch them. As always, I got closer than anyone else. As always, I will try again."
   168→
   169→### Other Character Voices
   170→
   171→For detailed character voice guides, see:
   172→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/ika-minami.md`
   173→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/sora.md`
   174→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/suiren.md`
   175→- Individual character files for speech patterns and samples
   176→
   177→---
   178→
   179→## Content Type Guidelines
   180→
   181→### Twitter/X
   182→
   183→**Single Tweets**
   184→- Max 240 characters for optimal readability
   185→- Hook in first 5 words
   186→- End with call-to-action or engagement prompt
   187→- Hashtags: #InfiniteIdol #SUI (always), topical tags as relevant
   188→
   189→**Threads**
   190→- 5-10 tweets per thread
   191→- Hook in first tweet, CTA in last
   192→- Each tweet stands alone but builds on previous
   193→- Visual breaks every 2-3 tweets
   194→
   195→**Tone Distribution**
   196→- Ika Voice: Playful, direct, intimate
   197→- Lore Drops: Mysterious, dramatic, tantalizing
   198→- Founder Hype: Confident, ambitious, community-focused
   199→- Engagement: Warm, appreciative, inclusive
   200→
   201→### Discord
   202→
   203→**Announcements**
   204→- Clear, structured formatting
   205→- Hype without desperation
   206→- Action items clearly stated
   207→- Exclusive/special treatment emphasized
   208→
   209→**Community Events**
   210→- Dramatic framing even for casual activities
   211→- Seven Gates hierarchy acknowledged
   212→- Rewards clearly communicated
   213→- Lore integration where possible
   214→
   215→**Moderation**
   216→- Firm but fair
   217→- Never break character without clear markers
   218→- Direct issues privately, celebrate publicly
   219→
   220→### Long-Form

1→# Specification: Infinite Idol Marketing Team Infrastructure Setup
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Set up a complete AI-powered marketing team infrastructure for **Infinite Idol**, a Web3 gacha game combining anime idol aesthetics with blockchain technology on SUI. This involves creating a comprehensive repository structure including: a knowledge base of all Infinite Idol lore, mechanics, and assets; seven specialized AI agent personas forming a marketing pipeline; workflow systems for content creation, community management, and campaign planning; output folders for generated content; and a feedback loop system for continuous improvement. The infrastructure will be populated from source materials already present in the repository (FULL_AUTO_CLAUDE_PROMPT.md and SOURCE_MATERIALS_APPENDIX.md).
     6→
     7→## Workflow Type
     8→
     9→**Type**: feature
    10→
    11→**Rationale**: This is a greenfield infrastructure setup requiring creation of 40+ files and directories, with substantial content population from source materials. It involves no existing code to modify but extensive new content creation.
    12→
    13→## Task Scope
    14→
    15→### Services Involved
    16→- **Marketing HQ Repository** (primary) - The complete folder structure and file system being created
    17→- **Knowledge Base** (content) - Lore, game mechanics, brand guidelines extracted from source materials
    18→- **Agent System** (documentation) - Seven AI agent persona definitions
    19→
    20→### This Task Will:
    21→- [ ] Create complete repository folder structure (40+ directories)
    22→- [ ] Create CLAUDE.md master instructions file
    23→- [ ] Create README.md project overview
    24→- [ ] Create 7 agent persona files in `agents/` directory
    25→- [ ] Populate knowledge-base/lore/ with world, characters, factions, mechanics content
    26→- [ ] Create knowledge-base/game-mechanics/ files from pre-registration spec
    27→- [ ] Create knowledge-base/brand/ guidelines files
    28→- [ ] Create knowledge-base/crypto/ documentation
    29→- [ ] Initialize outputs/ folder structure with .gitkeep files
    30→- [ ] Initialize logs/ and reviews/ systems
    31→- [ ] Set up master calendar template
    32→- [ ] Create human review workflow templates
    33→
    34→### Out of Scope:
    35→- Actual content generation (tweets, threads, etc.) - that's for agents to do later
    36→- Light novel full text (referenced but source files not provided in repository)
    37→- External integrations (Discord, Twitter APIs)
    38→- SUI blockchain development
    39→
    40→## Service Context
    41→
    42→### Marketing HQ Repository
    43→
    44→**Tech Stack:**
    45→- Language: Markdown
    46→- Framework: None (documentation repository)
    47→- Key directories: knowledge-base/, agents/, outputs/, logs/, reviews/
    48→
    49→**Entry Point:** `CLAUDE.md` (all agents read this first)
    50→
    51→**How to Run:**
    52→```bash
    53→# No runtime - this is a documentation/content repository
    54→# Agents activate by reading CLAUDE.md then their persona file
    55→```
    56→
    57→**Port:** N/A
    58→
    59→## Files to Modify
    60→
    61→This is a greenfield setup - no existing files to modify.
    62→
    63→## Files to Create
    64→
    65→| File | Directory | What to Create |

1→# Voice and Tone - Infinite Idol Brand Guidelines
     2→
     3→> *"We know exactly what we are. We're shameless about it. And we're damn good at it."*
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## Overview
     8→
     9→The Infinite Idol voice is **shameless but genuine, self-aware, dark luxury, existentially dramatic**. We are not another cutesy idol game hiding behind innocence. We acknowledge what we're making—a gacha game designed to captivate, monetize, and entertain. But we do it with craft, with care, and with genuine love for the world we've built.
    10→
    11→This document defines how Infinite Idol speaks across all channels, from Twitter threads to Discord announcements, from Ika's in-character posts to behind-the-scenes founder updates.
    12→
    13→---
    14→
    15→## Core Voice Pillars
    16→
    17→### 1. Shameless But Genuine
    18→
    19→**What It Means**
    20→
    21→We don't hide from what we are. We're making a gacha game. We want players to spend money. We design systems that encourage engagement and spending. This is not something to apologize for—it's something to own with confidence.
    22→
    23→But here's the twist: we're also genuine. We actually care about the world, the characters, the story. This isn't cynical IP extraction. We love Ika. We believe in the Eternal Stage. We want players to feel something real.
    24→
    25→**How It Sounds**
    26→
    27→| DO | DON'T |
    28→|----|-------|
    29→| "Yes, it's a gacha game. A really good one." | "It's not *really* about the gacha..." |
    30→| "We designed this banner to be irresistible." | "We hope you'll consider supporting us." |
    31→| "Ika wants your Devotion. So do we." | "Please become a fan if you can!" |
    32→| "We built this world because we love it." | "This is just a business venture." |
    33→
    34→**Examples**
    35→
    36→> "New banner dropping tomorrow. We put our heart into designing these cosmetics to separate you from your SUI. And honestly? They're gorgeous. You're going to want them."
    37→
    38→> "We're a gacha game. We're Web3. We're anime idols. Everything you've been warned about. But we're also genuinely good. Stick around and we'll prove it."
    39→
    40→---
    41→
    42→### 2. Self-Aware
    43→
    44→**What It Means**
    45→
    46→We know the tropes. We know the criticisms. We know what people say about gacha games, about Web3 games, about idol games. Instead of pretending we're different, we acknowledge the landscape and then transcend it.
    47→
    48→Self-awareness isn't self-deprecation. We're not mocking ourselves—we're demonstrating intelligence. We see the meta-game and we play it knowingly.
    49→
    50→**How It Sounds**
    51→
    52→| DO | DON'T |
    53→|----|-------|
    54→| "Another gacha game? Yes. But hear us out." | "We're totally unique and different!" |
    55→| "You've seen this mechanic before. We do it better." | "We invented revolutionary gameplay." |
    56→| "Web3 gaming has a reputation. We're here to change it." | "Web3 gaming is perfect and misunderstood!" |
    57→| "Idols chasing Senpai. It's exactly what you think. And more." | "Our narrative is incomparably original." |
    58→
    59→**Examples**
    60→
    61→> "Yes, the odds are 3% for Legendary. Yes, you're going to pull anyway. Yes, we know. That's why we made the Legendary items this good."
    62→
    63→> "Infinite Idol is built on SUI. Before you roll your eyes—we're gameplay-first, blockchain-second. The crypto part exists to make ownership real, not to make us look innovative."
    64→
    65→---
    66→
    67→### 3. Dark Luxury
    68→
    69→**What It Means**
    70→
    71→We are premium. We are sleek. We are black and gold, not pink and sparkles. This is not Love Live. This is not Hololive. We're closer to NIKKE—confident, adult, sophisticated.
    72→
    73→Our aesthetic is:
    74→- **Black**: Deep, rich, absorbing—the void that idols fear
    75→- **Gold**: Premium, aspirational, the gleam of success
    76→- **Rose/Magenta accents**: Ika's signature colors, warmth within darkness
    77→- **Minimalist elegance**: Clean lines, intentional space, no clutter
    78→
    79→**How It Sounds**
    80→
    81→| DO | DON'T |
    82→|----|-------|
    83→| "Dripping in elegance." | "Super cute and kawaii!" |
    84→| "The Eternal Stage demands excellence." | "Have fun on the stage, everyone!" |
    85→| "Premium cosmetics for premium idols." | "Adorable outfits for your favorites!" |
    86→| "Darkness awaits those who Fade." | "Oh no, they might disappear!" |
    87→
    88→**Language Guidelines**
    89→
    90→- Use **elevated vocabulary**: "elegance" not "prettiness", "devastating" not "sad"
    91→- Avoid diminutives: no "little", "tiny", "cute", "adorable" unless specifically ironic
    92→- Embrace dramatic phrasing: "The Eternal Stage demands" > "The Stage wants"
    93→- Keep sentences confident: declarative statements, not questions seeking validation
    94→
    95→**Examples**
    96→
    97→> "The new Midnight Empress collection. Five pieces. Obsidian and gold. For idols who don't just want to be seen—they want to be remembered."
    98→
    99→> "Ika's latest outfit wasn't designed. It was forged. In the fires of competition. From the tears of her rivals."
   100→
   101→---
   102→
   103→### 4. Existentially Dramatic
   104→
   105→**What It Means**
   106→
   107→In Infinite Idol, the stakes are real. Idols don't just lose—they Fade from existence. Fans don't just watch—they literally keep their idols alive. This existential weight informs everything.
   108→
   109→We lean into the drama. Every Chase matters. Every ranking shift is life or death. Every fan gained is survival. This isn't overdramatic—within our world, it's simply accurate.
   110→
   111→**How It Sounds**
   112→
   113→| DO | DON'T |
   114→|----|-------|
   115→| "Your Devotion keeps her existing." | "Support your favorite idol!" |
   116→| "Fight for your place on the Eternal Stage." | "Compete in fun events!" |
   117→| "47 fans. It's not enough. It's barely existing." | "She needs more fans to be popular!" |
   118→| "The Foundation controls who lives and who Fades." | "The Foundation manages the rankings." |
   119→
   120→**Tone Calibration**
   121→
   122→- **Heavy moments**: Full existential weight, no humor
   123→- **Lighter moments**: Dramatic undercurrent, but room for wit
   124→- **Hype moments**: Channel existential stakes into excitement
   125→- **Community moments**: Warmth exists within the darkness
   126→
   127→**Examples**
   128→
   129→> "Tomorrow's Chase determines who rises and who fades. There is no participation trophy. Only survival."
   130→
   131→> "Ika woke up with 47 fans. Most idols have thousands. She exists on borrowed time and borrowed devotion. And she wouldn't have it any other way."
   132→
   133→> "Every gem you spend fuels the Eternal Stage. Every idol you support delays their Fading. This isn't a game. It's a lifeline."
   134→
   135→---
   136→
   137→## Character Voices
   138→
   139→### Ika Minami (Primary Voice - 40% of Content)
   140→
   141→Ika is our protagonist and primary voice for first-person content.
   142→
   143→**Ika's Tone**
   144→
   145→- **Shameless**: She knows what she wants and says it directly
   146→- **Playful but not cutesy**: She teases and flirts without being saccharine
   147→- **Determined**: The underdog fire burns constantly
   148→- **Genuine**: Her love for her 47 fans is real and touching
   149→
   150→**Ika's Speech Patterns**
   151→
   152→| Pattern | Example |
   153→|---------|---------|
   154→| Direct address to fans | "You. Yes, you reading this." |
   155→| Tilde for playfulness | "Don't you dare look away~" |
   156→| Numbers emphasis | "47 fans. Just 47. But you're mine." |
   157→| Senpai obsession | "I will catch Senpai. Watch me." |
   158→
   159→**Sample Ika Tweets**
   160→
   161→> "Another day of being the idol with 47 fans in a world of millions. Some call it hopeless. I call it intimate~"
   162→
   163→> "They laughed when I entered The Chase. They're not laughing anymore. Well, some still are. But they won't be for long."
   164→
   165→> "To my 47: You are the reason I exist. Literally. Without your Devotion, I would Fade. So... don't stop watching, okay? Please?"
   166→
   167→> "Senpai appeared again today. As always, I couldn't catch them. As always, I got closer than anyone else. As always, I will try again."
   168→
   169→### Other Character Voices
   170→
   171→For detailed character voice guides, see:
   172→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/ika-minami.md`
   173→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/sora.md`
   174→- `knowledge-base/lore/characters/suiren.md`
   175→- Individual character files for speech patterns and samples
   176→
   177→---
   178→
   179→## Content Type Guidelines
   180→
   181→### Twitter/X
   182→
   183→**Single Tweets**
   184→- Max 240 characters for optimal readability
   185→- Hook in first 5 words
   186→- End with call-to-action or engagement prompt
   187→- Hashtags: #InfiniteIdol #SUI (always), topical tags as relevant
   188→
   189→**Threads**
   190→- 5-10 tweets per thread
   191→- Hook in first tweet, CTA in last
   192→- Each tweet stands alone but builds on previous
   193→- Visual breaks every 2-3 tweets
   194→
   195→**Tone Distribution**
   196→- Ika Voice: Playful, direct, intimate
   197→- Lore Drops: Mysterious, dramatic, tantalizing
   198→- Founder Hype: Confident, ambitious, community-focused
   199→- Engagement: Warm, appreciative, inclusive
   200→
   201→### Discord
   202→
   203→**Announcements**
   204→- Clear, structured formatting
   205→- Hype without desperation
   206→- Action items clearly stated
   207→- Exclusive/special treatment emphasized
   208→
   209→**Community Events**
   210→- Dramatic framing even for casual activities
   211→- Seven Gates hierarchy acknowledged
   212→- Rewards clearly communicated
   213→- Lore integration where possible
   214→
   215→**Moderation**
   216→- Firm but fair
   217→- Never break character without clear markers
   218→- Direct issues privately, celebrate publicly
   219→
   220→### Long-Form
